In accordance with this decision I submit a draft Bill.Charges Act, 1920, and continuing it until the 15th February, 1925, is to avoid the necessity for the introduction by the Railway Companies owning docks or harbours of separate private Bills before tho amalgamations under the Railways Act, 1921, are complete. It would be far more convenient to allow each of the four new amalgamated Companies to introduce Bills dealing with all the docks belonging to the Group. As the amalgamations will normally take place on the 1st July, 1923, an extension beyond the 15th February, 1924, is necessary and the extension of a year seems convenient.S3CRV2T.CP.3755.HARBOURS, DOCKS AND PIERS (TEMPORARY INCREASE OF CHARGES) BILL.Memorandum for the Cabinet by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Ministry of Transport.On October 27th the Home Affairs CommitteeThe object of amending the Temporary Increase of The Bill is quite simple. Possible opposition might come from shipowners who apprehend that dock and harbour charges will be maintained at an unduly high level. But so far as I can ascertain it is unlikely that the shipping interests will raise this point, as it is open to them at any time to ask the Minister to refer the existing charges to the Advisory Committee before whom they can state their case, a procedure which is preferable to opposition before, a Parliamentary Committee. Other dock and harbour authorities might seek to inelxide in the Bill powers to prevent railway-owned docks and harbours charging lower rates than competing ports, but I do not anticipate they will press this point on a temporary measure.(Signed) ARTHUR NSAL.Ministry of Transport. 18th February, 1922.
